title-group.article-title: Issuer Credit Ratings and Warrant-Pricing Errors

abstract.p: This paper examines how issuer credit relates to the level of warrant-pricing errors in Taiwan. The results demonstrate that the premia of warrants with high credit ratings have fewer pricing errors, implying that warrants with higher credit ratings are more fairly priced in terms of the Black–Scholes model. Using more parameters than in traditional option-pricing models, this study contributes to the literature by demonstrating that the credit ratings of warrant issuers have a critical impact on the prices of covered warrants.

ref.mixed-citation: These covered warrants are "bank-issued warrants" or "third-party warrants." We hereafter refer to these securities as warrants. According to Article 4 of the "Taiwan Stock Exchange Corpo- ration Rules Governing Review of Call (Put) Warrant Listings" announced on July 30, 2007, any enterprise that simultaneously operates underwriting, trading for its own account, and brokerage or intermediary services may apply for approval as a qualified issuer of call (or put) warrants.

The TAIFEX actively lists three (the next two quarterly months) or five (including the spot month and the next two calendar months) in-the-money and out-of-the-money option series, which are accompanied by their corresponding index or price levels, respectively.

Although certain related studies on the options pricing models extend the model proposed by Black and Scholes (1976) to consider stochastic volatility, jumps, and stochastic interest rates, we use the benchmark Black-Scholes model to focus on how the issuer's quality relates to warrant- pricing errors.

The TRC generally adopts, on a mutatis mutandis basis, the ratings criteria that are used by Standard & Poor's. There is a defined correlation and a resulting general mapping guideline between the TRC ratings scale and the Standard & Poor's scale. Similarly to Standard & Poor's, the TRC calibrates criteria by various means, including measuring default behavior across sectors and, over time, applying common approaches to risk analysis.
Because the numbers of listed warrants were seven and fourteen in 1996 and 1997 and the related trade volumes are small, we exclude the samples from these two years.

For accuracy in the empirical studies, we exclude certain uninformative warrants on the basis of the following criteria. First, we use the daily traded warrants with maturities having greater than five calendar days to expiration as our samples. This selection is appropriate because the prices of warrants with maturity dates of less than five calendar days are erratic, especially for deeply out-of- the-money warrants. Second, we discard all call warrants that violate the European-style boundary conditions, C < S - Ke~n. Finally, we use warrants with a strike/spot price ratio (moneyness, which is denoted as S/K for call warrants and K/S for put warrants) between 0.5 and 1.5.

We use the average deposit interest rates from the five major commercial banks, including the Bank of Taiwan, the Chang Hua Bank, the First Bank, the Hua Nan Commercial Bank, and the Taiwan Cooperative Bank. The interest rate data are available on the Web site of the Central Bank of the Republic of China.
Due to confidentiality concerns, we do not report the names of warrant issuers. Detailed information on the CR data is available upon request from the authors.
We use the quadratic approximation method proposed by Barone-Adesi and Whaley (1987) to adjust for the early exercise premium.

The random effects from the pooling regression are consistently rejected by Lagrange multiplier statistics (Breusch and Pagan 1980) and x2 statistics (Hausman 1978) at 5 percent statistical significance.
